comment:
[A reversed Benko. Personally
I wouldn't dream of letting my opponent play such a critical variation with an
extra tempo, but Bernard's play is nothing if not optimistic!]

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. c4 d4 3. g3 c5 4. b4 cxb4 5. a3 e6 6. Bg2 Nc6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Bb2 bxa3 9. Nxa3 Bc5 10. Ne1 e5 11. Nd3 Bd6
comment:
[Black makes the
critical decision to allow the capture of the black-squared bishop. 11...Be7
would of course permit White to regain his pawn by 12.Bxc6+, but it would by
no means clearly good to do so.]

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. c4 d4 3. g3 c5 4. b4 cxb4 5. a3 e6 6. Bg2 Nc6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Bb2 bxa3 9. Nxa3 Bc5 10. Ne1 e5 11. Nd3 Bd6 12. Nb5 e4 13. Nxd6+ Qxd6 14. Ba3 Qe6 15. Nf4 Qe5
comment:
[15...Qxc4 16.d3 is awkward for Black. Now, my original intention was
also 16.d3, but after rejecting that and 16.Rb1, I fortunately settled on a
strong move.]

[Now I had nned 22.Bf5 Qh6 23.Bxc8 hxg3
24.Bd7+! bt when I noticed that Black could play 22...Qd5 instead, I looked
for something better.]
